Problem:
Consider a discrete-time system governed by the equation \\( x_{n+1} = f(x_n) \\\), where \\( f(x) = A x \\) with A being a square matrix. We also use a linear operator \\( T(x) = B x \\), where B is another square matrix, to transform the initial state.

If we apply \\( T(x) \\) to an initial vector \\( x_0 \\) and subsequently let the system evolve according to \\( x_{n+1} = f(x_n) \\) without further intervention, will the state \\( x_N \\) at time step N be the same as if \\( x_0 \\) was directly evolved to step N under the same system equation?
Explanation: Applying \\( T(x) \\) modifies the initial state to \\( B x_0 \\). The new trajectory starting from \\( B x_0 \\) is evolved by repeated applications of A, resulting in \\( A^N B x_0 \\). This differs from \\( A^N x_0 \\) unless A and B commute.
